title: universal credit slept married man christmas day
story: A SINGLE mum left so destitute by Universal Credit that she sold herself to a married man for £ on Christmas Day has revealed she has been unable to escape prostitution.Charlotte, , from South London, says she feels trapped by poverty and cannot afford to quit sex work.Charlotte fell into the dire situation after running up debts while waiting five weeks for her first Universal Credit payment.As part of The Suns Make Universal Credit Work campaign, we are fighting to slash the five week wait to two weeks.The Sun first revealed her tragic struggle on the new benefit system in December, telling how Charlotte was left with just £. a day to live on after bills.She began selling sex for as little as £, and at times she performs sexual favours on up to  men a week while her son is at school.At times I have had to sleep with men for some change - just £ or £ so I can buy some food in Iceland, just so my son doesn’t go hungry, she says.Charlottes story is far from unique, with increasing numbers of women turning to sex work to support their families.Last month MPs announced a new inquiry into women turning to prostitution because of Universal Credit - which has been dubbed survival sex by campaigners.And while working families can claim back up to % of their childcare costs, they must find the money to pay for childcare upfront - we’ve heard of families waiting up to  months for the money.Working parents across the country told us they’ve been unable to take on more hours - or have even turned down better paid jobs or more hours because of the amount they get their benefits cut.Thats why The Sun has launched our Make Universal Credit work. We demand the Government makes the following changes to help hard-working famililes before its too late. We want you to:Together, these changes will help Make Universal Credit Work.Things have not improved for the former housekeeper, who has been forced to borrow money to pay for furniture and did not have enough cash to celebrate her eight-year-old son’s birthday.“I got my son a little truck for his birthday but that was it, she said. “He was happy to get something as I’ve had to sell the toys he has just to charge the electric and the gas,”Charlotte charges men £ for sex and other favours - bringing in around £ every week. She sees one client whenever she can as she appreciates the “regular” work.In fact, the mum feels so let down by the Government she claims her clients are the only people she can trust.Charlotte, who lives on an estate, had to give up her job when she had her son because she couldnt afford childcare.She moved onto Universal Credit in January  but fell £ behind on her rent while waiting for her first payment and was threatened with eviction.She says: “If I didn’t have to wait so long for my first payment, I would have been OK.“Something always goes wrong - five weeks is too much. I’m still just about managing now.“Winter has been hard, I’ve had to keep the house warm and the lights on, but it’s been so expensive to do.Her sons dad pays nothing towards his upkeep and while she received a £ loan from the government to tide her over when she moved onto Universal Credit last year, she claims she wasn’t told by her local job centre that it would need to be repaid.“That was the final straw when everything changed, and I saw how much debt I was in… the payments and the household bills, it all built up,” she says.Charlotte now receives £-a-month in Universal Credit after her rent has been paid to her landlord and her debts, including the £ furniture loan, are taken off.At one point, after shed paid the rest of her bills, she was left with just £. a day for her and her son to live on.Other women have also claimed that a long wait for their first Universal Credit payment has forced them into sex work.Julie, , from Merseyside told the BBC she had been left “so ashamed” after being forced to turn to sex work after an EIGHT-week wait for her Universal Credit payment.“I didnt go out looking for it, I said no at first ... it wasnt until about three weeks later that I said OK, yeah, because I thought I need to, because I need money’,” she said.Its something I never ever thought I would be ever capable of doing.”Apply for an advance - Claimants are able to get some cash within five days rather than waiting weeks for their first payment. But its a loan which means the repayments will be automatically deducted from your future Universal Credit pay out.Alternative Payment Arrangements- If youre falling behind on rent, you or your landlord may be able to apply for an APA which will get your payment sent directly to your landlord. You might also be able to change your payments to get them more frequently, or you can split the paymentsyoure part of a couple.Budgeting Advance - You may be able to get help from the government to help with emergency household costs of up to £youre single, £youre part of a couple or £you have children. These are only in cases like your cooker breaking down or for help getting a job. Youll have to repay the advance through your regular Universal Credit payments. Youll still have to repay the loan, evenyou stop claiming for Universal Credit.Cut your Council Tax - You might be able to get a discount on your Council Tax or be entitled to Discretionary Housing Paymentsyour payments arent enough to cover your rent.Foodbanks - If youre really hard up and struggling to buy food and toiletries, you can find your local foodbank who will provide you with help for free. You can find your nearest one on the Trussell Trust website.Women like Charlotte are often too ashamed to tell their families that they have resorted to prostitution to survive.“I can’t talk to anyone. It’s the guilt mainly. My family don’t know - they wouldn’t be happy. They’d be angry, furious, upset. They would be so judgemental.My son still doesn’t know about what I do for money either.”“And I’m sure there are other women out there in worse situations than me.”Charlotte is struggling with her mental health at the moment and is having therapy for a second time – but she hasn’t admitted what she “does on the side” as she doesn’t think her counsellor would understand.She is considering going to college to do a course as she wants to be an author, but feels things are stacked against her.“I know I’ve got lots to work on, but it’s too much sometimes,” she says.“I keep thinking, why is this happening “They say Universal Credit is working, but who is that for Why are people getting poorer but the government don’t care  Evensomething changes, I can’t erase what I’ve done now.Officials say that advances are available from day one on Universal Credit - and that Brits can get up to  per cent of their cash upfrontthey need it.But delays getting the welfare payments are causing women to rack up debt and some are selling their bodies while they wait for help, charities have said.We know from the stories of women that have contacted us that the delays in processing universal credit and the drop in benefits is financially crippling.It is essential that the vulnerable are protected and their welfare is paramount.”A representative for Beyond The Streets, which works to help women who have suffered sexual exploitation, said: We welcome the investigation in to failures in universal credit and the increase in survival sex.In October, MP Frank Field shocked the House of Commons when he revealed women in his Birkenhead constituency were selling themselves for sex for the first time as a result of hardship caused by the introduction of Universal Credit.After The Sun shared Charlottes story with Mr Field, he said he would write to Department for Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd about her case.Here we have yet another awful example of Universal Credit pushing vulnerable mothers, who are trying to protect their children, to rock bottom and beyond, he told The Sun.The DWP insists safeguards are in place to make sure all repayments are affordable and sustainable.It also aims to give people help to find routes out of the sex industry, with personalised work coaches in place to help people looking for alternative roles.The department insists it has responded quickly to feedback on Universal Credit by continuing to pay Housing Benefit for two weeks after people move on to the new system. Other legacy benefits will follow suit shortly.Ms Rudd has responded to the Suns campaign, saying shes listening to Sun readers as she tries to improve Universal Credit for working families.A DWP spokeswoman told The Sun: We’re committed to getting help to people when they need it most, and advance payments and budgeting support are available.Work coaches are trained to spot vulnerable people, including those working in the sex industry, and offer appropriate support.”*Charlottes name has been changed.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: let the spirit of notre dame bring hope to all of us in the uk this easter
story: For many this might include a break from work, study or school, simply enjoying spending time with families and loved ones.Yet, there are thousands in the UK who do not have this chance.In one of the wealthiest countries in the world, heralded for its history and culture, modern day slavery is thriving.According to the Home Office, there are more than , victims of human slavery in the UK.Many more are at risk of falling through the cracks, away from the view of the authorities.These are real people — be they a woman or girl in the illegal sex trade, a man forced to work on a construction site, or a child married against their will. None of them are free.Leaders from across our faith communities are standing together to speak out against slavery.Last year the Church of England and the Catholic Church launched the Safe Car Wash App to help drivers report slavery at car washes — one industry alone that’s thought to have thousands of enslaved workers.After just six months, users have reported over , suspected cases, helping the police to tackle this plague.In my own Diocese I know there is crucially important work going on to support these victims.At All Souls Church in Langham Place, at the heart of the West End, the charity Tamar provides essential support and advocacy by reaching out to women who are suffering through sexual exploitation.Tamar takes inspiration from the two stories of women in the Bible being badly mistreated by men and society,The appeal has built on the work of the Clewer Initiative, which has called for a community -wide response to modern slavery — developing partnerships between the Church, statutory and non-statutory agencies, to create a network of advocates seeking to end modern day slavery.As we celebrate the new le of Jesus Christ, let us remember that new le comes not just after death but for those that are living.The UK recognised a staggering , victims from  countries in , including adults who had been used for organ harvesting and children that were forced into sexual exploitation.At present, trafficked victims have just  days support after being freed before they are expected to leave the UK and are deported by the Home Office.During this short time, they are given accommodation, financial aid, medical treatment, counselling, a support worker, a translator and legal advice.We want the government to: Back Lord McColls proposed bill, which suggests all victims of modern slavery should be given a years support to recover.Alongside that they should be given special support to help them, including housing benefits, financial help and other services.This week’s devastation of Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris, and the remarkable demonstrations of solidarity and generosity that have emerged in its aftermath, are testament to the power of community and show the spirit of resurrection in action.If we could apply that same spirit to the terrible injustice of slavery in our communities, through working together, looking closely for what is hidden in plain sight, and supporting the excellent work of charities, we can give new le to those thousands of victims of modern slavery.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make title: sri lanka bombings easter sunday churches hotels colombo
story: What is the current death toll and which hotels and churches were affected  Heres the latest.The first reports of attacks came about .am and six blasts happened within a short space of time.Three were at churches - carried out as Christians attended Easter mass - and three were at luxury hotels.The churches hit were in the Kochchikade district of the capital, Colombo, in Negombo, to the north of the capital, and in the eastern city of Batticaloa.The hotels that came under attack were the Shangri-La, Kingsbury and Cinnamon Grand hotels in Colombo.The blasts are thought to have been carried out by nine suicide bombers including one who studied in the UK.The Sri Lankan government has named local Jihadi terror group National Thowheeth Jamaath as being responsible for the horric attacks.The NTJ is a radical Muslim group in Sri Lanka that was linked last year to the destruction of Buddhist statues.Hours after the first six were reported, there have been two more fatal blasts in the city - an explosion at a hotel in Dehiwala which killed two, and another in a flats in Dematagoda which reportedly killed three police officers and led to arrests, taking the shocking attacks up to eight.In addition, a six-foot pipe bomb was intercepted and destroyed by the Air Force on the way to Colombo International Airport.The atrocities came ten days after Sri Lankas police chief issued alert on possible attacks.This key intelligence was not passed on to the Sri Lankan government just days before the attacks.Ranil Wickremesinghe, the Sri Lankan prime minister, acknowledged that “information was there” about possible attacks.Two days after the attacks, ISIS claimed responsibility for the bombings and released a picture of the terror mastermind and seven henchmen responsible.The death cults Amaq news agency claimed that the terrorists involved in the attacks were fighters of the Islamic State.So far  have been killed with  of the victims coming from one church and more than  have been injured.Among the dead are  foreigners and they include eight Brits, several Americans, one Dutch, one Chinese, two Turkish and one Portuguese national have been confirmed dead.Among the dead are British lawyer Anita Nicholson, , and her son Alex,  and daughter Annabel, who were queuing for breakfast at the Shangri-La hotel when a suicide bomber detonated a device at .am.Anita’s husband Ben survived the attack and frantically searched the wreckage for his family.Daniel Linsey, , and Amelie Linsey, , were killed after escaping a suicide bomber in the Shangri-La hotel - only to run into a deadly second blast.Lorraine Campbell, , from Manchester, was named the last of eight British victims killed in the Easter Sunday massacre.Three children of Danish billionaire Anders Holch Povlsen were also killed in the blasts.Hotels frequented by tourists, the luxury Shangri-La Hotel, Cinnamon Grand and The Kingsbury Colombo, were also targeted in the deadly series of attacks.Worshippers were also attacked this morning, with those at an Easter mass targeted at St Anthonys Shrine, a Catholic Church in Kochchikade, Colombo .Blasts were also reported at St Sebastians Church in Negombo, a majority Catholic town north of Colombo, and at Zion Church in the eastern town of Batticaloa - where more than  people are thought to have been injured.

title: sri lanka easter bombings opinion past horrors
story: There was a real party atmosphere as many Christians were dressed up to go to see family and go to church together.The streets were crowded with people going shopping and taking the day off.There was much merry-making. It has been ten years since the civil war and everyone is getting back to normal.But after the bombs it was complete and utter chaos. People were running in the streets. It was helter skelter.People were literally running to hospital. It was chaos. Bodies everywhere.Like many Christians in Sri Lanka I had a day off so I travelled to see my mother just outside Colombo so we could go to church for morning Mass.But at around am messages flashed up on a WhatsApp group with journalists that there was a sudden blast at St Sebastian’s Church in Negombo.At first we thought it must be an electric transformer exploding or an accident.But then we heard of another at St Anthony’s Church, followed by a born-again Christian church in Batticaloa.I then knew it was well-planned and organised simultaneous attack.Two blasts in at Shangri-La, then the Cinnamon Grand and the Kingsbury came under attack.Security was beefed up and a curfew was imposed and the streets are empty.But everyone is worried there may be more blasts. People are on vigil.It’s shocking. People were so relaxed. It’s been a peaceful environment since the civil war ended.This terrorist attack has brought back memories of the horrors of the past.Easter is a huge event in Sri Lanka. We had New Year four days earlier and there are sales in the shops.The whole week was a party with people enjoying le like never before.But now Colombo is paralysed and no one is allowed outside.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may must walk
story: She announced a general election which, only a couple of weeks previously, she had insisted she would not call.As she s to Downing Street this morning, once again refreshed from the Welsh hills, she needs to make an equally dramatic decision: To resign immediately as Conservative leader and to stay on as Prime Minister only as long as it takes to elect a new leader.May is far from the first Prime Minister to have demonstrated a loosening grip on reality while ensconced in the Downing Street bunker, but surely even she can see that the game is up.The dissent towards her in her own party is staggering.A shocking poll for the Conservative Home website at the weekend revealed that  per cent of Conservative Party members are planning to vote for Nigel Farage’s Brexit Party in the European elections. This was not a poll of wider Tory voters but of people who pay an annual subscription to the party.If this group of around , people are not prepared to vote for their own party, then what chance have the Tories in attracting votes from the wider electorate But it gets worse — even elected Tory representatives are planning to rat on their party in the European elections.A Survation poll suggests that four in ten Conservative councillors are planning to back the Brexit Party too.Loyalty, it used to be said, was the Tories’ secret weapon.Not any more.The party has become like an army whose frontline troops have started burrowing beneath enemy lines — not in order to plant explosives beneath its positions, but in the hope of joining it in its trenches.No Conservative leader will find it easy to turn around the situation, but at least a new face, with some new ideas and a fresh perspective on how to solve the Brexit impasse, would have a chance.Anything would be better than being led round and round in circles by a Prime Minister who has become tired and stuck.Every time May comes to the despatch box after some new, devastating vote in the Commons, I find myself thinking: Surely she must have a fresh strategy now.Then I find myself groaning to learn that no, still she seems to think that the answer is to keep on plugging her failed deal.To huge numbers of British people, May has become a large part of the problem.What was once seen as her greatest asset — resilience — is now seen as plain stubbornness.It has become impossible to imagine any satisfactory outcome to Brexit until she is gone.Sadly, I fear that May herself cannot see this.Like John Major in the last, wretched years of his premiership, I fear she has convinced herself that she is an asset to her party and her country when almost everyone  can see that the opposite is true.As with Major in the mid s, every day that May remains in Downing Street is adding to the scale of defeat the party faces at the ballot box.The only dference is that then the beneficiary was the moderate Tony Blair.This time around, an unpopular but stubborn Tory leader is adding rocket fuel to the chances of an unreformed Marxist, Jeremy Corbyn, becoming Prime Minister.I know May is desperate to achieve some sort of legacy before she leaves Downing Street, butshe resists much longer her main achievement will be an indirect one — it will be to let in a Labour government which s Britain to the sort of punitive tax rates which drove a brain drain of iniduals and businesses from the country in the s.It is a great shame that May did not resign last December, when  of her MPs voted against her in a confidence vote.Her margin of victory — she won  per cent of votes — would have constituted a substantial mandate in an open leadership contest.But this was not a leadership contest.It was a no-confidence vote in a sitting Prime Minister, in which anything less than a resounding victory would have been unsatisfactory.Given that more than  Conservative MPs are members of the Government — and were therefore duty bound to support their Prime Minister in a confidence vote — May failed even to carry with her a majority of her backbenchers.And that was before the multiple Commons defeats for her deal, which have led to open rebellion in the Cabinet.Were such a vote to be held now, it is inevitable that many ministers who reluctantly backed her in December would no longer feel they needed to do so.Under the Conservative Party’s rules, May cannot be challenged again in a no-confidence vote for a full  months after the last one. But there are rumblings to change this rule.Graham Brady, Chairman of the  Committee, which represents backbenchers, is reported to be planning to visit May next week to tell her to resign before the end of June.But that won’t be soon enough. Before then, the Tories face twin wipeouts in the local and European elections. The latter may be utterly pointless but nevertheless, a derisory performance is still going to be deeply traumatic when it happens.Theresa May’s ministers have dutully supported her in the past.Her duty is now to step aside immediately, before she accidentally ends up leading her party to an even greater humiliation in a general election than the one it suffered in .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: home owners gardens airport revamp
story: Alex and June Carr claim their peace and quiet has been shattered by the proximity of Southend Airport, as huge passenger jets are seen taxiing just yards away.Their home is in a row that backs onto a new taxiing strip, resulting in steady disruption of fumes and noise between am and pm every day.Neighbour Janet Marchant, , has lived in a bungalow next to the Essex airport for seven years without any major problems.But she says the new strip means a plane now prepares for take-off near her home every  minutes.You cant have a conversation in the garden with anyone because you cant hear them and when we are inside with the door closed we have to pause the TV until the plane has gone past, she said.We worry about our grandchildren coming around and the enjoyment of having people over for BBQs is ruined.I love my garden and used to do a lot of gardening but now it is all spoiled with the noise and the smell.According to Ms Marchant, the issues began in November  when the airport revamped its Charlie Taxiway - the route used for planes taking off from the eastward runway.The works started at the far end of the runway near Rochford and are expected to end soon, but its feared the disruption will continue.Southend Airport has so far received more than  inidual complaints, but every aircraft concerned was found to be operating normally and legitimately in every case.Ms Marchant claims shes received a letter from the airport telling her not to complain further - but insists she is not going to stop.The pollution and smell is awful and its really noisy, she said.My partners breathing is now not so good and my neighbours say they cant sit outside or open their windows at certain times of the day.Yesterday there were about  that went past and one was sat waiting for about  minutes before it took off and it was incredibly noisy.It cant be good for your health.Southend Airport said Ms Marchant is suspended, not banned and the decision was made by the Civil Aviation Authority, not the airport.A spokesman from the airport said: London Southend Airport is very proud of both its long heritage, having been an airport since , and the important, positive role it plays in the community.We appreciate that the Wells Avenue properties were built close to the Charlie Taxiway, and are currently engaging with those residents through quarterly meetings and are actively investigating active measures to reduce noise.The airport has ambitious plans to grow, and will continue to work closely with the CAA to ensure the airport remains safe and environmentally responsible for all our stakeholders.We have recorded and investigated over  inidual complaints and found that in every case, the aircraft concerned was operating normally, legitimately and within the Airports operating framework.

title: gonorrhoea sti sign blisters rash hand
story: The unnamed -year-old was diagnosed with gonorrhoea after turning up at AE with a rash.She told doctors at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center in Dallas, that the rash had erupted that morning.They examined her and found it was covering her arms, legs, trunk and scalp.The patient was also complaining of muscle aches, fever and pain in both ankles.She then admitted to having unprotected sex with a new partner two weeks earlier.Doctors, suspecting an STI, prescribed the woman antibiotics.Dr Melissa Mauskar, who treated the patient, wrote in a case report published in the New England Journal of Medicine: Blood cultures grew gram-negative diplococi that were identied as Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which confirmed the diagnosis.The patients symptoms abated with antibiotic treatment.Three months later, at a follow up appointment, the woman told doctors she was feeling well and had suffered no further rashes or joint pains.Also known as the clap, gonorrhoea is one of the most common STIs.More than , Brits were diagnosed with the infection in , while million are infected globally every year, according to the World Health Organisation.While its easily treated,it goes undetected gonorrhoea can spread to affect other parts of the body.Thats what is known as disseminated gonorrhoea infection .Rashes and joint point, like that affecting the Texas patient, are known signs of DGI, according to MedScape.In severe cases DGI can cause gonococcal meningitis, pericarditis and endocarditis - both infections of the heart.Symptoms of gonorrhoea tend to develop within two weeks, but can sometimes appear months later.However, around one in ten men, and one in five women wont have any obvious symptoms, which means the STI can go untreated for some time.In typical cases, these symptoms will affect women:Meanwhile, blokes should watch out for:Last month it emerged two Brits caught super gonorrhoea after steamy sex sessions in Ibiza.One of the women became the first in the UK to catch the drug resistant strain on British soil.Doctors have warned the emergence of this drug-resistant strain, dubbed super gonorrhoea because its so hard to treat, is just the beginning of a much wider STI boom.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: united airlines racism monkey slur
story: Cacilie Hughes, an actress, asked United Airlines worker Carmella Davano for assistance only to be met with a racist tirade, its claimed.Hughes, , had flown home to Houston, Texas, from Michigan when she encountered the employee at the baggage reclaim.She approached Davano for a refund code, prompting the woman to erupt at United’s terminal inside George Bush Intercontinental Airport and call her a “monkey” and a “shining monkey,” Hughes told the New York Times.Hughes said: I was humiliated. I was crying and I was the only black woman in the area.Her lawyers said Davano also told Hughes to stop looking at her with her “monkey face.”Other passengers at the terminal witnessed the exchange and tried to intervene, but were unsuccessful, its alleged.Hughes then asked another United employee to call the police, a request that was denied, leading her to contact authorities herself.Davano was later criminally charged with disorderly conduct for using a racial slur, the laywers said.Court documents obtained by the New York Times show that the misdemeanour charge was filed against Davano, who could not be reached for comment, one month after Houston police issued her a citation for profane and abusive language in a public space.The outlet reports that two witnesses also told responding officers that they heard Davano direct the slurs toward Hughes, who appeared in ’s “Focus” alongside actor Will Smith.She’s also the vice president of the Big Sister Little Sister Mentoring Program, according to the nonprofit group’s website.Davano has not ed to work for United since the alleged incident, according to a statement from the airline.The statement reads: At United, we proudly hold ourselves to the highest standards of professionalism and have zero tolerance for discrimination of any kind.We have withheld the employee from service since the night of the incident pending an internal investigation. Upon conclusion of the investigation, we will take any and all appropriate corrective action up to and including termination.Hughes lawyers said the incident is the latest example of a company-wide pattern of racial discrimination by United Airlines, citing a Nigerian woman’s lawsuit alleging that she was kicked off a flight last year after a white passenger said she smelled.The attorneys also referenced Eric Murdock, a former NBA point guard who sued the airline for  million in December for kicking him out of an exit row before allowing a white passenger to take his seat.A statement from the lawyers said: Racial slurs like shining monkey should be relics of history, not resurrected to fuel the fire of racism faced by so many African Americans in today’s society and condoned on United Airlines flights.A version of this story originally appeared on New York Post

title: self charging pacemaker end surgery replace batteries
story: The device is designed to correct an irregular rhythm and is charged as the heart beats.It means users do not need an operation to replace empty batteries, as is necessary every six to ten years with existing pacemakers.The new gadget uses a hi-tech “energy harvester” that is wrapped around the heart and generates electricity from movement.With each beat of the heart, more electricity is produced to power the pacemaker.The Georgia Institute of Technology, in the US, has successfully tested the device in pigs, whose hearts are about the same size as those of humans.Study leader Dr Zhong Lin Wang said the energy harvested by his new gadget is higher than that needed for a human pacemaker.It was able to correct potentially fatal heart conditions in the animals.Around , people are fitted with a pacemaker in the UK each year. The gadgets send pulses to the heart to keep it beating regularly.They are the size of a matchbox, fit in the chest, and consist of a battery, tiny computer circuit and wires, which attach to the heart.Dr Wang said: “Millions of patients rely on implantable medical electronic devices.“However, their batteries are generally bulky, rigid, and have short letimes. Power source has impeded the progress of IMEDs.”British experts welcomed the “exciting” breakthrough but warned it could be some years before the devices are ready for human use.This is because they need to be shown to be safe and capable of generating and storing enough power over the long-term.Prof Tim Chico, from the University of Sheffield, said: “Millions of patients undergo insertion of pacemakers to treat fast or slow heart rhythms.“These are very effective but unfortunately battery le is limited. contagious skin condition caused by tiny mites burrowing into the skin, where they feed and lay eggs.After three to four days, the larvae hatch and move to the surface of the skin where they mature into adults.Scabies like warm place, such as skin folds, between fingers, under toenails, or around the buttock and breast creases.They can also hide under watch straps, bracelets or rings.The main symptom is intense itching thats usually worse at night and a skin rash where the mites have burrowed.The condition is usually spread through prolonged periods of skin-to-skin contact with an infected the incubation period.The man, from Spain, had been to see a doctor three months earlier about red scaly skin on his scalp and hands, but skin scrapings tested at the time didnt show mites.So, he was thickened skin on the face, neck, between his fingers and toes, and the genitals.The patient was given a course of treatment and his symptoms cleared up within two weeks.Crusted scabies is highly contagious due to the large number of mites found on the skin.It typically affects older people, particularly dementia patients, and those with a lower immunity.But it can also develop in people story: Time is running out for the PM to avoid having to hold euro elections, with the poll to elect MEP on May  - four weeks tomorrow.As cross party talks to pass the EU agreement began again yesterday after the Easter break, frustrated Mrs May accused Labour of dragging its feet.No is considering trying to speed up the process by asking Parliament to raty the Brussels deal anyway by introducing the Withdrawal Agreement Bill that enshrines it in law.Home Secretary Sajid Javid and Commons Leader Andrea Leadsom were among several senior ministers who lobbied the PM for the emergency move during a meeting of her top table yesterday.It would be high risk without any newly-established majority ready to support it.But one senior minister told The Sun: “We’ve got to do something.“Being seen to do nothing and allowing Brexit just to drt is killing us out there on the doorstep.“Talks with Labour are going nowhere, and were never going to.”The PM’s told the Cabinet yesterday that talks with Labour had been “serious but had also been dficult in some areas such as in relation to the timetabling for the negotiations”.Her official spokesman added: “Progress needs to be made urgently”.In another sign that the talks were close to collapse, Jeremy Corbyn hit back at Mrs May to accuse her of refusing to compromise with Labour, who are demanding a customs union with the EU.The Opposition boss said: “There’s got to be a change to the Government’s approach.“They cannot keep on just regurgitating what has already been emphatically rejected three times by Parliament”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: NewsopinionThe Brexit Party should be renamed the nasty partyThe Brexit Party is on a roll thanks to the defection of Ann Widdecombe. But what is Nigel Farages real agenda ShareCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsopinionNigel Farages Brexit Party is set to win the European elections "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Theresa May and Jeremy Corbyn hold the first PMQs since the Easter break today with even less to agree about than usual. Talks between their two parties on Brexit are deadlocked  and it is hard to find anyone in Westminster who believes an agreement can be reached. Mrs May is now running out of options on Brexit. One possibility under consideration is to put the Withdrawal Agreement Bill before Parliament and defy MPs to vote it down. It is hard to see how this will work when,anything, Tory opposition to the agreement has hardened since the emergence of Farage’s Brexit Party.   The Brexit Party has a slick media operation, momentum and, as of this morning,  the backing of Ann Widdecombe who will be standing as a candidate in the Europe elections .  The former Conservative minister said she felt “compelled” to come out of retirement in order to deliver the referendum result.  Herto frontline politics may or may not be what a weary nation has been wishing for. Success in the European elections would buy the Brexit Party two important commodities: money and exposure.  The generous funding of MEPs can be used to help bankroll domestic campaigns, while broadcasting regulations also require the TV stations to give air time to parties with elected representatives. Farage’s new outfit is benefiting from being a single issue party. So far the Brexit Party has been deliberately reticent about setting out any policies beyond its Ronseal-style name. Voters attracted to the party may want to ask whether Farage is still in favour of privatising the NHS, scrapping some racial equality laws and axing parental rights. They may also want to think twice before lending support to someone who has addressed a rally by the hard-right Alternative for Germany party and is an apologist for the National Front in France.Perhaps this is the spiritual home of Ms Widdecombe who voted against repealing Section , introducing the Equality Act and civil partnerships.

On Thursday  May, millions of Brits will go to the polls in the European Parliament elections - two months after we were supposed to leave the EU. The drama around Brexit has encouraged many larger-than-le characters to come out of the woodwork and stand for the  British seats up for grabs. Those who win will enjoy an MEPaposs salary of , Euros per year plus generous travel and office allowances - until Brexit happens, and theyaposre booted out of the Parliaement. So who is standing and who will you get to pick from in your area  Here are some of the big faces putting themselves forward, plus full listsof who is standing where. Scroll down for the full list by area.  On Thursday  May, millions of British voters will elect  MEPs to sit in the European Parliament - until Brexit happens. The elections were not meant to happen but have been forced on the UK after Theresa May agreed to delay Brexit until October . Voting is ided into large regions of the country, with each selecting between  and  MEPs using a form of proportional representation. Seats in each region are allotted to each party depending on what share of the regional vote they received. Sothe Tories win three seats in South East England, the highest three candidates on the Tory aposlistapos become MEPs. The actual aposDaposHondt systemapos for deciding which party gets which number of seats is very complicated. In each region, the party with the most votes gets the first seat then its total is ided by two and the party with the most votes in the second round gets the second seat. The process is repeated via a complex formula until all seats have been dished out. If youaposre into that sort of thing thereaposs a full explainer _EN.pdf" rel"nofollow"here. The Tories are expected to receive a hammering from Nigel Farageaposs Brexit Party, which has never faced an election before but contains many UKIP defector MEPs. Change UKwill be trying to scoop up the anti-Brexit vote in what is this groupaposs first ballot box test too. Those fringe movements could hit both Labour and the Tories hard, especially becausethe seats are chosen through a form of proportional representation, andEU elections were previously ripe for protest votes. In the last elections in , UKIP won  seats Labour won  the Tories won  and the Greens won . Nigel Farage will be leading the charge for his new Brexit Party, which despite only just setting up has enjoyed polling numbers in the mid-teens. Deputy Labour leader Tom Watson and Labour peer Maurice Glasman have warned the elite elite-basher poses a serious threat to Labour. He vowed to put the fear of God into our MPs - they deserve nothing less in comments that led to accusations he was making dog-whistle threats. Lord Buckethead The comedy character is back after becoming a viral internet sensation when he stood against Theresa May in . This time he is planning to stand against Nigel Farage in South East England.Because he is not part of a list he will need to outstrip the might of the big parties to get elected. But he has been boosted by more than £, in crowdfunding - three times what he needed for his £, deposit. Rachel Johnson  Rachel Johnson, the sister of Tory Boris, is to stand for anti-Brexit party Change UK in the South West region. The journalist who has long campaigned against Brexit became the second sister of a prominent Brexiteer to join a new party in as many weeks. Jacob Rees-Moggaposs sister Annunziataalso announced she would stand in the election for Nigel Farageaposs Brexit Party. She took a swipe at her brother, saying she did not want to see Brexit “rubbing out my children’s prospects and chances of living and travelling and working in Europe”. Ann Widdecombe Conservative Party stalwart Ann Widdecombe sensationally quit - to stand for the Brexit Party in the South West. The -year-old had been a staunch Tory for  years - serving as Shadow Health and Home secretary. But she has joined Nigel Farageaposs fledgling party on a mandate to hurry up and get Britain out of the EU. LGBT rights campaigners condemned theof Ms Widdecombe - who spent decades battling equal rights - just days after Nigel Farage claimed his new party would be intolerant of intolerance. The former Tory grandee voted against equalising the age of consent at , civil partnerships and the repeal of Section . And in  she defended gay conversion therapy - which Theresa May has branded abhorrent and vowed to ban. The former minister prompted raised eyebrows when he announced he would be standing for Labour - as second choice for the South West Region. The arch-Remain peer is most definitely not following Jeremy Corbynaposs official line on Brexit. He wants to cancel our leaving the EU - saying Brexit can and should be stopped. Carl Benjamin  The UKIP candidate refused to apologise for saying he wouldnapost even rape Labour MP Jess Phillips. The -year-old who styles himself aposSargon of Akkadapos even doubled down, saying his comments were justied because sheaposd been a giant bitch. In combative exchanges, Mr Benjamin - who is second on UKIPaposs South West regional list - told journalists: Iaposm not answering your questions, Iaposm not apologising for anything, you dirty, dirty smear merchants.  The isive UKIP leader is almost guaranteed to re-win his seat as heaposs top of the partyaposs list in London. He has courted far-right EDL founder Stephen Yaxley-Lennonand defended Carl Benjaminaposs claim he wouldnapost even rape a female MP. Annunziata Rees-Mogg Jacob Rees-Moggaposs SISTER was announced as one of the first candidates for Nigel Farageaposs Brexit Party. Gavin Esler  Former BBC top dog Gavin Esler branded Brexit Britain a worldwide joke as he confirmed heaposll stand in the London region for Change UK. Ex-MP Katy Clark is a key ally of Jeremy Corbyn as the former political secretary to the Labour leader. story: NewsHuawei: Chinese phone giant to help build UK G network despite Cabinet rowHuawei will reportedly get limited access to the network thanks to Theresa May - despite fears it could be forced to co-operate with Chinese spyingShareByDan BloomOnline Political EditorGavin Cordon:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsHuawei has welcomed the reported decision "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailChinese phone giant Huawei has reportedly won permission to help build Britainaposs new G network - despite a blazing row at the highest levels of the UK government.Prime Minister Theresa May is said to have given the green light to the telecoms giant despite warnings from her Home, Defence and Foreign Secretaries.Security figures warn giving the firm access to Britainaposs critical communications network will be risky, because it could be forced to co-operate with the Chinese state. The US has banned the Huawei from its government networks and urged others in the Five Eyes intelligence alliance - the UK, Australia, New Zealand and Canada - to do the same. According to the Dailyand the , Huawei will not be allowed to supply core parts of the G network. But it will reportedly be given limited access to provide non-core infrastructure like antennas after Mrs May chaired a meeting of the National Security Council yesterday. The decision was blasted by senior MPs - who said it did not go far enough and Huawei should be banned entirely.    Home Secretary Sajid Javid, Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt, Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson, International Trade Secretary Liam Fox and International Development Secretary Penny Mordaunt were said to have raised fears during yesterdayaposs meeting, according to the . And Tom Tugendhat, Tory chairman of the Commons Foreign Affairs Committee, warned today the decision raises concerns and will erode trust with UK allies. He warned it was very dficult to separate out core and non-core parts of the network. We’re talking about a system that will need constant upgrading, he told the BBC. Every time you do that you’ve got to open up the system to your technology partner. And he tweeted: Allowing Huawei into the UKaposs G infrastructure would cause allies to doubt our ability to keep data secure and erode the trust essential to Five Eyes cooperation. Thereaposs a reason others have said no.    Ciaran Martin, chief executive of the UKaposs National Cyber Security Centre, did not confirm the announcement but insisted security measures would be in place. He told the BBC: When an announcement is ready the relevant Secretary of State, Jeremy Wright, will come to Parliament. And then after that there will be detailed explanations of the security framework weaposre going to put in place to make sure we have sufficiently safe G networks. He also insisted a review that will be announced in due course will be about much more than Huawei. Huawei has denied having ties to the Chinese government. But critics question how independent any large Chinese company can be. There is a legal obligation on firms to co-operate with the stateaposs intelligence agencies. Some critics have expressed concerns that the Chinese government could require the firm to install technological back doors to enable it spy on or disable Britainaposs communications network. Last month a government-led committee set up to vet Huaweiaposs products said it had found signicant technological issues with its engineering processes leading to new risks to the UK network.  MI chief Alex Younger has said Britain needs to decide how comfortable it is in allowing Chinese firms to become involved. And the head of GCHQ Jeremy Fleming has spoken of both opportunities and threats which they present. In a statement to the BBC, Huawei said it welcomes the reports that UK consumers will have access to the fastest and most reliable networks thanks to Huaweiaposs cutting edge technology. However, the firm cautioned that we await a formal government announcement. Downing Street refused to comment on the report. A spokeswoman said: We donapost comment on NSC discussions. A Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport spokeswoman said the security and resilience of the UKaposs telecoms networks was of paramount importance. As part of our plans to provide world class digital connectivity, including G, we have conducted a review of the supply chain to ensure a erse and secure supply base, now and into the future, the spokeswoman said. This is a thorough review into a complex area and will report with its conclusions in due course.

title: lyra mckee theresa jeremy corbyn
story: NewsLyra McKee: Theresa May and Jeremy Corbyn attend murdered journalists funeralThe pair will miss Prime Ministers Questions to pay tribute to the -year-old shot dead by the New IRAShareCommentsByMichael McHughDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsMourners attending Lyra McKees funeral have been asked to wear Harry Potter clothes "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May and Jeremy Corbyn will attend the Belfast funeral of murdered journalist Lyra McKee today.The Prime Minister and Labour leader will forego their usual debate at PMQs to pay their tribute to the -year-old.Mrs May will be replaced by her deputy David Lidington at PMQs while Mr Corbyn will be represented by Shadow Foreign Secretary Emily Corbyn. Ms McKee was shot dead as she observed clashes between police and New IRA dissidents on the Creggan estate in Londonderry on April . Her family has paid tribute to her as a best friend and confidante. Her funeral will take place in St Anneaposs Cathedral, Belfast, at pm, and she will later be laid to rest in Carnmoney cemetery.  A tribute from her mother Joan, brothers Gary and David, and sisters Joan Hunter, Nichola Corner and Mary Crossan said: On Thursday th April our beautul Lyra was taken from us. A daughter, a sister, an aunt, a great-aunt, a partner, a niece, a cousin, and above all, a best friend and confidante to so many of us. A friend to all, a gentle innocent soul who wouldnapost wish ill on anyone. Such a warm and innocent heart, she was the greatest listener, someone who had time for everyone. The McKee family added: She was a smart, strong-minded woman who believed passionately in inclusivity, justice and truth. Lyra spoke to and made friends with anybody and everybody, no matter what their background, those of all political views and those with none. This openness, and her desire to bring people together, made her totally apolitical.  They said: We would ask that Lyraaposs le and her personal philosophy are used as an example to us all as we face this tragedy together. Lyraaposs answer would have been simple, the only way to overcome hatred and intolerance is with love, understanding and kindness. Sara Canning, Ms McKeeaposs partner, said previously: Our hopes and dreams and all of her amazing potential was snuffed out by this single barbaric act. Ms McKeeaposs funeral is intended to be a cross-community, cross-border and multi-cultural service, while members of the National Union of Journalistswill form a guard of honour. Various political and community leaders are due to attend, including Taoiseach Leo Varadkar, President of Ireland Michael D Higgins and Irish Minister for Foreign Affairs Simon Coveney.  Those attending were asked to wear Harry Potter and Marvel Comic merchandise in tribute to the journalistaposs love of both works.Miss McKeeaposs family asked that only family flowers are laid, but a donation can be made via a GoFundMe page set up by the NUJ.The New IRA admitted responsibility for the murder on Tuesday in a statement given to The Irish News. Using a recognised code word, the group offered full and sincere apologies to Ms McKeeaposs family and friends, claiming: We have instructed our volunteers to take the utmost care in future when engaging the enemy, and put in place measures to help ensure this. The New IRA is an amalgam of armed groups opposed to the peace process and it recently claimed responsibility for parcel bombs sent to London and Glasgow in March. story: NewsErrors we all make with food in our fridge - and how doing it right can save cashFrom the correct temperatures to portion control and taking a shelfie - tips you need to save moneyShareCommentsByNada Farhoud:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsSorting the fridge out properly could save a lot of time and cash "Get the biggest money stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMouldy cheese, weeks-old ham or a plate of leftovers from your Sunday roast dinner. Chances are most of what you’ll find in the recesses of your fridge will end up in the bin. Last year we threw away . million tons of food. Of this, five million tons was still edible. Confusing food labels such as “once opened” instructions, are inconsistent and unclear as to whether they are recommendations on food safety or quality –contributing to food waste. But also simply turning down the temperature in your fridge can help to keep food fresher. Three-quarters of us run our fridges too warm – a move which could prevent up to . million of tonnes from being dumped and save each family a small fortune. So what temperature should your fridge be and which shelves are best for what foods  Read are guide on how to cut down on food waste. It is better for the environment and your pocket too. What is the correct temperature for a fridge    Experts say the optimum overall temperature is between c and c. Aside from food going off before its best-before date, there are several warning signs that your fridge is at the wrong temperature. Modern appliances have a built-in thermometer with some activating an alarmthe temperature drops below or above the optimum range. Condensation on the inside walls means it is too warm as the fridge’s gas is being turned into liquid, which may contaminate food on the lower shelves. If it’s too cold, ice maybe visible at the back. This could also be caused by a faulty door allowing warm air from the outside into the fridge. Donapost overfill the fridge  The more stuffed your fridge shelves become, the harder it is to keep cool. Experts recommend turning down the thermostat by one degreeit is packed. But an empty fridge is not efficient either. To prevent the fridge getting too cold, place a couple of jugs of water on a shelf to fill up space. Or you can turn the temperature setting up a notch. Embrace your freezer Many of the items in our fridges will be suitable for home-freezing, which can extend their shelf le massively. It doesn’t have to be on the day of purchase either, just as long as it is before the use-by date. Portion control Avoid cooking too much by sticking to recommended serving sizes listed on packaging. When we eventually did break-up, he became obsessed.    He hacked into my Facebook to read all of my messages and accessed the camera I used to check on my pets while Iaposm out to spy on me. His stalking campaign left me feeling unsafe in my own home, but Iaposm just glad heaposs out of my le.  Helen first met Mark in April  when he was called out to her house through his job with British Gas. She said: I was having my Hive wireless heating system fitted on the Friday. At first, Helen was flattered by the attention she received from Mark.    She said: He was really friendly in his messages. He seemed very open and honest and seemed to know all the right things to say. It was nice to have someone to talk to about my recent failed marriage that wasnapost close to the situation. We started chatting a lot in messages and then he began popping over to my house for a cup of tea - he was a shoulder to cry on. Weaposd gotten quite friendly and it was nice. It started out as friendship at first, but then he started saying things like he felt like he was falling in love with me. Iaposd just separated from my husband and the attention was nice. It was what I wanted to hear so our friendship developed into romance.  She said she noticed after two months that things didnapost seem right. He became quite obsessive and paranoid, she continued. If I didnapost message him back straight away, Iaposd start to get a withheld number ringing me which was clearly him checking up on me. He said that now - after talking to me - he felt he could carry on with le, with me being in it he wouldnapost be so depressed. I told him: aposI canapost be that person in your le, you have to make yourself happy. You canapost rely on other people.apos Helen said Mark left her alone for a short period, before things took a sinister turn. She said: I actually didnapost hear from him for a while, but one day I was in my living room - trying to get the jewellery out of a candle Iaposd bought in November last year, when I heard my camera move. It stopped me in my tracks. I had bought the home security camera to keep an eye on my  cats and one dog, Rico, a Yorkshire Terrier rescue, while I was out. The only way the camera could move isI accessed it from the app on my phone and directed it to. I logged into the app and saw it said apostwo viewersapos at the top. I knew straight away it was Mark and I confronted him. I instantly knew it was him so I text him saying: aposBefore you lie, Iaposve got the camera interface so I can see where it can be logged in from.apos I didnapost have it, but I knew it was him and he admitted it too. He was basically spying on me. It left me feeling unsafe in my own home so I told him: aposIaposm going to the policeapos. He spent the day crying down the phone, telling me I was going to ruin his career and his le and that his daughter would be taken away from him. He said heaposd just got engaged to his girlfriend. But I knew it had to stop and he wouldnapostI didnapost take action. With the support of a womenaposs organisation I was working with on my placement at university, I went to the police station to report it. Helen was so upset that she later suffered panic attacks, had trouble keeping food and drink down and wanted to move out of her home. At court, Wellings admitted stalking and was given an -week prison sentence, suspended for  months in April. She said he would have to pay Helen £ compensation, a £ victim surcharge and £ prosecution costs. She said: I went along to the court case and read my victim impact statement. I was very emotional and had to stop a couple of times. Mark just looked down at the floor and up at the ceiling to avoid looking at me. I thought he might have apologised through his barrister but he didnapost. He knew the right things to say and do. I look back now and think aposwhy didnapost I pick up on that apos At the time, I thought it was lovely that somebody was caring about me that much, but now I realise he was smothering me. When you let someone into your home you donapost expect them to betray that trust or the position they are in.    If someone was to come to your door and tell you theyaposre a convicted stalker and said: aposCan I come in and fix your boiler apos I canapost imagine many people would say aposyesapos. If anyone  is in a similar position to me, my advice would be to go to the police straight away. If they are working for a business and theyaposve got your details through their work go to the top. Itaposs not acceptable. It was only after we contacted the CEO of British Gas that they took action and Iaposve been told Markaposs been dismissed with immediate effect. They apologised and were honest in saying the correct procedures werenapost followed. He should have been suspended straight away and shouldnapost have been allowed to work and go into other peoplesapos homes. Itaposs caused a huge amount of distress seeing him driving around in his British Gas van and felt like a big two middle fingers stuck up at me - like what heaposs done doesnapost matter. Iaposve been assured theyaposve launched an internal investigation and Iaposve suggestedanyone accused of something as serious as stalking needs to be removed straight away, whether they are guilty or not guilty, because of the risk it poses to other people. title: true story worlds richest man
story: NewsTrue story of worlds richest man who refused to pay kidnapped grandsons ransomOil tycoon J Paul Getty also moaned about having to pay his own sons medical bills when he was battling a brain tumourShareCommentsByJane Lavender:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsTe billionaire even moaned about paying his son, Timmys medical bills as he was dying of a brain tumour "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email J Paul Getty was one of he worldaposs richest billionaires after making his fortune in oil.But the magnate is not just famous for his wealth but also for being one of the meanest billionaires ever.He famously refused to the ransom to save his grandsonaposs le following his kidnap in .In revenge, the kidnappers cut off the teenageraposs ear and posted it to his frugal grandfather. But the frugal billionaireaposs mean streak was evident long before the famous kidnapping, which has been turned into both a film and a TV series.    The oil magnate’s love of money over family extended to his terminally ill son. Timmy’s tale is perhaps the truest reflection of Getty’s frugality. He was the son of Getty’s fth and final we Teddy Getty Gaston, who died last April aged . In her memoir, the American singer revealed the extent of Getty’s tight pockets. The American-born ­industrialist moaned about having to foot Timmy’s medical bills when he went blind from a brain tumour. While Timmy battled for his le, Getty failed to see him for four years.    The miser missed his son’s birth and, when Timmy died at the age of , Getty did not attend the funeral – sending Teddy a note apologising for being busy. Timmy idolised his father, however. In her book, Alone Together, Teddy remembers Timmy’s love for his father during his dying days in heart-breaking detail. “He was full of love for his dad,” she writes. “ He never knew he was the richest man in the world. He’d heard it but he’d say, ‘That’s what the world sees. I see him as my own darling daddy, whom I love’. How he missed Paul.” She adds: “Sometimes I sat ­quietly beside him while he seemed to be ­thinking and he’d suddenly say, ‘When will he come home  I wish I had a daddy like other boys have. Do you think he really loves me  I wish I could talk to him.’  “‘Well, let’s talk to him,’ I’d say, and we’d call Paul. He’d tell everyone then for days that he’d spoken to his father. He never asked for any material things, all he wanted was to see his dad. He never begrudged the fact that Paul never came. He was too loving… and yet in his heart he needed a father.” So Getty was as absent as he was parsimonious. Teddy never forgave him for failing toto his American home from England during Timmy’s illness, citing it as the reason for their orce in .  In letters sent in the years leading up to Timmy’s death, Teddy pleaded with her husband toand comfort their son. But he never did. Teddy wrote to Getty in : “I know now that you aren’t coming home to us, because I know you don’t want to, and so I have come to the tragic realisation that you have no real concern for Tim or me.” At that time, in , Getty was ­negotiating the groundbreaking deal to secure oil rights in Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, which would see him become America’s first billionaire. But not only did Getty refuse tohome – he cruelly built up  hope in his little boy’s mind. He regularly promised to visit Timmy in New York hospitals after his ­operations, but again never did so.  The Getty Oil boss was even heartless enough to complain about doctors’ bills on the phone to Teddy as Timmy lay screaming in pain in the room next door. Teddy remembers bursting into tears and hanging up the call, feeling alone and afraid as she battled the toughest years of her le without her husband. “Timmy needed his father,” she says in her memoir. “I needed him, too. In the days after Timmy’s initial brain tumour diagnosis aged six in , many members of the family, including Teddy’s brother Ware, nephews, nieces and Timmy, excitedly gathered to wait for Getty as the Queen Mary liner pulled into New York, told by the tycoon that he would be on board. But a message from the captain confirmed he had never fulfilled his promise of travelling across the Atlantic. Getty had not only failed to board the ship – he had not even bothered to let his family know.  Two days later, Timmy had to undergo one of his countless operations, hopes dashed of having daddy by his side. Later that year Getty wrote a letter from the Ritz Hotel in Paris which would be callous from a pauper, but was positively cruel from a billionaire. He said: “I hope Timmy can keep away from doctors, except for a  visit. I don’t think doctors can do much for him now, except for a check-up, and that shouldn’t be more than  unless the doctors charge on the ability to pay and not on a tarf and I avoid such doctors.” He told Teddy the money she paid for a pony to comfort Timmy must come out of her own purse.  Teddy died when he was just -years-old. But it was the abduction of his -year-old grandson, John Paul Getty III, that showed the world just what a miser J Paul really was. The free spirited -year-old was living in Rome with his father, J. Paul Getty II when he was kidnapped. He had apparently been trying to woo a Belgian go-go dancer in the Piazza Navona in Rome when he disappeared before dawn on July , . Paul was buying a comic book at a newsstand when he was abducted by three men who knocked him out by hitting him with a gun.  The men drove him to a cave in the southern part of the country and tied him up while they probed the Getty family for the hefty ransom which shockingly his grandfather refused to pay. No-one knows exactly the sequence of events but a ransom note read: Dear Mother: I have fallen into the hands of kidnapers. Don’t let me be killed! Make sure that the police do not interfere. You must absolutely not take this as a joke… Don’t give publicity to my kidnaping.” At first police didnapost believe the boy had been kidnapped but they realised it was no joke when the kidnappers called to say they would send the boyaposs mother one of her sonaposs fingers and demanded million from his grandfather.  Initially J Paul Getty reportedly refused to pay - commenting that he had  other grandchildren. He was quoted as saying that he opposed paying the kidnappers in principle, because it only encourages kidnapping as a criminal practice. The billionaire is reported to have said: “I have  other grandchildren andI pay one penny now, then I’ll have  kidnapped grandchildren.” His refusal to pay lead to devastating consequences for the teenager. John Paul was subjected to months of agonising torture and even had part of his ear cut off, which was then sent to a local paper. In early November an envelope was delivered to the Rome daily  Il Messaggero,  Rolling Stone reports .  It contained a lock of reddish hair and a severed human ear.This is Paul’s first ear, read a typewritten note. If within ten days the family still believes that this is a joke mounted by him, then the other ear will arrive. In other words, he will arrive in little bits.apos The delivery of the ear was apparently enough for Getty Snr to agree to pay the ransom - but at a reduced rate of millionAt the time he was estimated to be worth around £bn.  But this wasnapost an act of grandfatherly compasion, J.Paul was told the ransom would be tax deductable by his accounts. Paul was finally released five months after he was first abducted. He flagged down a truck driver, who drove him to the nearest police station where officers noticed his missing ear. Following his ordeal, Paul developed an addiction to alcohol. And nine years after his released was left quadriplegic following an overdose of methadone and valium. He died, aged , in .

story: NewsSri Lanka bombings: Dads hugged at hospital while searching for British childrenMatthew Linsey, who lost two children in the Sri Lanka attacks, and Ben Nicholson, whose we and two children were also killed, met at a hospital while looking for their loved onesShareCommentsByChris kitching:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsBen Nicholson lost his we Anita, son Alex and daughter Annabel "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Two fathers who lost children in the Sri Lanka terror bombings hugged as they desperately searched for their families following the attacks.Matthew Linsey and Ben Nicholson met at a hospital while looking for their British children after two suicide bombers targeted the Shangri-La hotel in the capital Colombo. Mr Nicholsonaposs we Anita, , son Alex,  and daughter Annabel, , were killed in the first explosion as they ate breakfast at the Table One restaurant. Mr Linsey and his children - Daniel, , and Amelie,  - ran out of the room but the siblings died after a second blast aimed at killing survivors trying to flee.    Mr Linsey, , has previously told how he was forced to make the heart-wrenching decision over which injured child to save. He believed Amelie was less seriously injured and went to hospital with Daniel as his daughter remained with another survivor. Daniel was pronounced dead and Mr Linsey, a US-born investment banker, later found out that Amelie had died as well. At the hospital, Mr Linsey, from London, encountered British lawyer Mr Nicholson, , whose family was based in Singapore.   Devastated Mr Linsey, whose children were dual UK-US citizens, told the Daily Mail: We hugged and tried to support each other. We helped each other.He said he is still in touch with Mr Nicholson, adding: He is a lovely man. I spoke to him [Tuesday]. He is still there trying to organise the repatriation of his family.In an interview with CNN, the father, whose face is scarred from shrapnel, said Daniel and Amelie had gone down to breakfast buffet before him and filled up his plate.Shortly after he joined them the first blast went off.  As his eldest son David, , held him outside their London home, Mr Linsey said: I wanted more to drink. I was going to get it, my daughter said, aposNo, Iaposll get itapos – and then the bomb went off and they both were running toward me, and Iaposm not sure whether thataposs what killed them or not. I knew thereaposd be another bomb because there always is. The Linseys tried to escape but they were hit by the second blast near lts on the hotelaposs third floor. Mr Linsey has been left tormented by what,anything, he could have done dferently to protect his teenage children. He said: Maybe I should have just stayed and covered them with my body.  The trio had gone on an Easter holiday together while Mr Linseyaposs we and two other children stayed home. Mr Linsey said a woman who survived the blast offered to take Amelie downstairs to an ambulance while he carried Daniel. Both of his children were unconscious. He travelled with Daniel, a student at Westminster Kingsway College in central London, in an ambulance, and at the hospital he tried to revive his son by massaging his heart. Mr Linsey then went looking for Amelie, a pupil at Godolphin and Latymer School in Hammersmith, west London, and found her body under a hospital sheet. A doctor helped the grief-stricken father reach the US Embassy, and he flew home to London later Sunday amid fears of more attacks on the island.  Eight British nationals were killed in the attacks since claimed by ISIS. In the aftermath, Mr Nicholson paid tribute to his we Anita, a lawyer, and their children. The family lived in Singapore and were on holiday in Sri Lanka. He said: Mercully, all three of them died instantly and with no pain or suffering. I am deeply distressed at the loss of my we and children. Anita was a wonderful, perfect we and a brilliant, loving and inspirational mother to our two wonderful children. The holiday we had just enjoyed was a testament to Anitaaposs enjoyment of travel and providing a rich and colourful le for our family, and especially our children. Alex and Annabel were the most amazing, intelligent, talented and thoughtful children and Anita and I were immensely proud of them both and looking forward to seeing them develop into adulthood.

title: a chance for budding reporters at dundee schools to take over the tele
story: This week the Tele is launching a new initiative to inspire budding newshounds in the city to get involved with their local paper.Tele Takeover aims to encourage kids to become interested in journalism by giving pupils the chance to have their work published in the paper.From Friday, we will be inviting the city’s schools to fill one of our news pages with stories written by P  pupils or third and fourth year high school students.A mixture of news and feature articles will be published on the page, covering both local issues and current affairs.Selected schools have already been contacted and are on board, with the project being extended to all schools in the city after the summer holidays.Jenner Heffell, head teacher at Rosebank Primary, was the first to sign up her school.To celebrate, DC Thomson’s own cheeky schoolboy Dennis visited Rosebank for a Tele Takeover launch event.Jenner said: “As soon as we heard about it we wanted to get involved – it’s a fantastic idea.“The children get to work directly with specialists and learn lots of new skills and how they’re applied.“It gives a dferent purpose to their writing, knowing that it’s going to be in the newspaper and everyone in the city will be able to see it.“The pupils are really excited, especially because they’re the first ones to do it.”Jenner added that Rosebank is keen to inspire pupils to have dreams and career ambitions and that taking part in Tele Takeover will give them a taster of the world of journalism.Paul Clancy, executive director of Dundee City Council’s children and families service, is backing the initiative.He said: “Literacy in all forms is important for young people’s learning but having it executed in a live context and using it in a vocational way strengthens their skills greatly.“This gives youngsters the opportunity to apply what they’ve already learned at school and further expand their learning in a professional workplace.“To then have their names published in the paper is great – everyone loves to see their name in print.”Tele editor Dave Lord said:“We are really excited to be launching the Tele Takeover this week.“It will be another showcase for pupils to develop their writing skills and I can’t wait to see what they come up with.“Being able to communicate effectively is absolutely vital in the world of work and we hope the Takeover will help children to develop their confidence in this area.“The support of schools as we launch the project has been vital and I would like to thank them all – and Dundee City Council – for supporting the initiative in such a wholehearted manner.”Michael Stirling, head of Beano Studios Scotland, said: “Dennis was traditionally famous for creating notorious news and shocking headlines through rebellious mischief, so I think it’s great to imagine how he’d get on actually writing the news.“I’d love to find out and I think the Tele’s fantastic campaign is our best way of discovering what would happen to the news when we let our kids takeover.”Michael Stirling, head of Beano Studios Scotland, said: “Dennis was traditionally famous for creating notorious news and shocking headlines through rebellious mischief, so it’s great to imagine how he’d get on actually writing the news.“I’d love to find out and I think the Tele’s campaign is our best way of discovering what would happen to the  news when we let our kids take over.”
